Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Raffles Holdings" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(January 2022)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **Raffles Holdings** was the parent company of [Raffles International](/wiki/Raffles_International), owned by [Temasek Holdings](/wiki/Temasek_Holdings) which is the investment arm of the [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) government. In 2005, Raffles Holdings' [hotel](/wiki/Hotel) business ranked 17th or 18th in the world in terms of market capitalization and number of rooms, all marketed under the Raffles and [Swissôtel](/wiki/Swiss%C3%B4tel) brand names. ## History The company was incorporated on 26 August 1995. On 18 July 2005, Raffles Holdings announced its sale to [Colony Capital, LLC](/wiki/Colony_Capital,_LLC) for about US$1 billion, including outstanding debt. The deal, worth 1.72 billion Singapore dollars, included all 41 hotels and resorts. Its most prominent establishment was the luxurious 103-suite [Raffles Hotel](/wiki/Raffles_Hotel) in Singapore, built in 1887. [CapitaLand Ltd.](/wiki/CapitaLand), Southeast Asia's largest property developer that owned 59.7 percent of Raffles Holdings, would gain the equivalent of US$362 million from the sale and plans to pay shareholders a special dividend of 23 U.S. cents a share. The cash price for the hotels was 1.45 billion Singapore dollars, or US$859 million. [SGX](/wiki/Singapore_Exchange): R03
